FICHTER_2011SummerTeachingSyllabus                        Student Worker                    uuid:7382f3bb-e3d7-4865-be75-a71721f743b8     uuid:8e348457-bf60-497c-9136-ae6a8bbe0639                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            endstream endobj 16 0 obj  >stream  h26T0Pw/+Q0L)66 )I0i"cC* RS� �#  endstream endobj 17 0 obj  >stream  h|AK1Fܚ[A)UP(b/I76nd2A{n, ,պ%x߉uar:![kE[7M3f8&{ >da|J'm82ڐ%H w Ag>h]A"m؜N=y?4rKWX^�GK3  endstream endobj 18 0 obj  >/Filter/FlateDecode/ID[ ]/Info 32 0 R/Length 91/Root 34 0 R/Size 33/Type/XRef/W[1 2 1]>>stream  hbb�&Fay& g $ 0e2*dXa@HIf$T&/q ``G0 ��~ V  endstream endobj startxref  116  %%EOF

Linda Dowling Almeida    | Glucksman Ireland House | New York University                                          Skip to page Content.     NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                       Home       About Us       Undergraduate Studies       Graduate Studies       Academic Initiatives       Events       Membership       Community             Stay Connected           sign up       like us on Facebook       follow us on Twitter       watch us on Youtube       now on iTunes       listen to our radio hour                 Home > People > Linda Dowling Almeida             Linda Dowling Almeida     Adjunct Assistant Professor of Irish Studies   Ph.D., NYU, 1996, M.A. Boston College, B.A. Boston College       Office Hours:   Tuesday 1:00-3:00pm and by appointment   Email:            Areas of Research/Interest:   20th Century Irish-American History, Society and Culture, particularly the post-World War II period.       External Affiliations:   New York Irish History Roundtable   Bio   Linda Dowling Almeida received her BA and MA degrees from Boston College and was invited to teach in the Center for Irish Studies at New York University by inaugural director Robert Scally in 1997, upon completion of her doctorate at NYU under the supervision of American immigration historian, David M. Reimers.      Specializing in twentieth century immigration, Professor Almeida has focused primarily on the ‘New Irish’ of the 1980s and 1990s, publishing a chapter in the first volume of Patrick O’Sullivan’s significant multi-volume history, The Irish World Wide (Leicester University Press), entitled “And They Still Don’t Know What They’re Looking For,” a chapter about Irish American culture in Ireland in the 1950s (University of Cork Press), edited by Dermot Keogh, Finbar O'Shea and Carmel Quinlan as well as an essay entitled “Irish America 1940-2000” for Making the Irish American (New York University Press) edited by J.J. Lee and Marion R. Casey.      Her book, Irish Immigrants in New York City, 1945-1995 , comparing those who arrived in the 1950s with their counterparts thirty and forty years later, was published by Indiana University Press in 2001 and was critically reviewed as a valuable addition to American ethnic history and the placement of Irish America within the mainstream narrative of American historiography. She is a veteran member of the New York Irish History Roundtable and edits that organization’s newsletter and the reviews section of its annual journal.      Professor Almeida offers classes in the history and literature of Irish America. Her historical approach to Irish American writing encourages students to not only understand the evolution of the Irish American community across time, but to understand its significance within the broader American culture. Since 2005 she has worked with Professor Marion Casey to develop an oral history program that offers undergraduates the opportunity to interview local Irish Americans as part of a semester long intensive course on interviewing and research techniques that results in student produced oral history records. These records are deposited for public access in the Archives of Irish America of NYU's Division of Libraries.     Of her teaching, Professor Almeida says, "Teaching at Glucksman Ireland House at NYU gives me the chance to challenge myself and the students I teach every day as we engage in the history and literature of Irish America. Our location in the middle of New York City gives us the opportunity to go out and explore the world we study, which we do every semester, whether it's Ellis Island, the Hunger Memorial, the Tenement Museum or conducting oral histories with members of the Irish American community. When we are in the classroom, few teaching spaces at the university are as comfortable or conducive to discourse and discussion than our building. We are truly spoiled in such an inviting learning atmosphere. I cannot imagine teaching anywhere else."   Selected Works:   "The Irish in America, 1940-2000," Making the Irish American: The History and Hertiage of the Irish in the United States, Marion R. Casey and JJ Lee, eds, NYU Press, 2006       Irish Immigrants in New York City, 1945-1995 , Indiana University Press, 2001      "'And They Still Haven't Found What They're Looking For': A Survey of the New Irish in New York City," Patterns of Migration , Patrick O'Sullivan, ed., 1992      "The Lost Generation: The Undocumented Irish in New York City in the 1980s," 1989, New York Irish History      Editor, 1993-1994, New York Irish History (journal)   Updated on 01/08/2015                       Áras Glucksman na hÉireann                      Ollscoil Nua Eabhrac                  Glucksman Ireland House                  New York University                  One Washington Mews                  New York, NY 10003                  U.S.A.             Directions     Phone: 212.998.3950   Fax: 212.995.4373         Email:        ireland.house@nyu.edu         Sitemap | Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Linda Dowling Almeida    | Glucksman Ireland House | New York University                                          Skip to page Content.     NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                       Home       About Us       Undergraduate Studies       Graduate Studies       Academic Initiatives       Events       Membership       Community             Stay Connected           sign up       like us on Facebook       follow us on Twitter       watch us on Youtube       now on iTunes       listen to our radio hour                 Home > People > Linda Dowling Almeida             Linda Dowling Almeida     Adjunct Assistant Professor of Irish Studies   Ph.D., NYU, 1996, M.A. Boston College, B.A. Boston College       Office Hours:   Tuesday 1:00-3:00pm and by appointment   Email:            Areas of Research/Interest:   20th Century Irish-American History, Society and Culture, particularly the post-World War II period.       External Affiliations:   New York Irish History Roundtable   Bio   Linda Dowling Almeida received her BA and MA degrees from Boston College and was invited to teach in the Center for Irish Studies at New York University by inaugural director Robert Scally in 1997, upon completion of her doctorate at NYU under the supervision of American immigration historian, David M. Reimers.      Specializing in twentieth century immigration, Professor Almeida has focused primarily on the ‘New Irish’ of the 1980s and 1990s, publishing a chapter in the first volume of Patrick O’Sullivan’s significant multi-volume history, The Irish World Wide (Leicester University Press), entitled “And They Still Don’t Know What They’re Looking For,” a chapter about Irish American culture in Ireland in the 1950s (University of Cork Press), edited by Dermot Keogh, Finbar O'Shea and Carmel Quinlan as well as an essay entitled “Irish America 1940-2000” for Making the Irish American (New York University Press) edited by J.J. Lee and Marion R. Casey.      Her book, Irish Immigrants in New York City, 1945-1995 , comparing those who arrived in the 1950s with their counterparts thirty and forty years later, was published by Indiana University Press in 2001 and was critically reviewed as a valuable addition to American ethnic history and the placement of Irish America within the mainstream narrative of American historiography. She is a veteran member of the New York Irish History Roundtable and edits that organization’s newsletter and the reviews section of its annual journal.      Professor Almeida offers classes in the history and literature of Irish America. Her historical approach to Irish American writing encourages students to not only understand the evolution of the Irish American community across time, but to understand its significance within the broader American culture. Since 2005 she has worked with Professor Marion Casey to develop an oral history program that offers undergraduates the opportunity to interview local Irish Americans as part of a semester long intensive course on interviewing and research techniques that results in student produced oral history records. These records are deposited for public access in the Archives of Irish America of NYU's Division of Libraries.     Of her teaching, Professor Almeida says, "Teaching at Glucksman Ireland House at NYU gives me the chance to challenge myself and the students I teach every day as we engage in the history and literature of Irish America. Our location in the middle of New York City gives us the opportunity to go out and explore the world we study, which we do every semester, whether it's Ellis Island, the Hunger Memorial, the Tenement Museum or conducting oral histories with members of the Irish American community. When we are in the classroom, few teaching spaces at the university are as comfortable or conducive to discourse and discussion than our building. We are truly spoiled in such an inviting learning atmosphere. I cannot imagine teaching anywhere else."   Selected Works:   "The Irish in America, 1940-2000," Making the Irish American: The History and Hertiage of the Irish in the United States, Marion R. Casey and JJ Lee, eds, NYU Press, 2006       Irish Immigrants in New York City, 1945-1995 , Indiana University Press, 2001      "'And They Still Haven't Found What They're Looking For': A Survey of the New Irish in New York City," Patterns of Migration , Patrick O'Sullivan, ed., 1992      "The Lost Generation: The Undocumented Irish in New York City in the 1980s," 1989, New York Irish History      Editor, 1993-1994, New York Irish History (journal)   Updated on 01/08/2015                       Áras Glucksman na hÉireann                      Ollscoil Nua Eabhrac                  Glucksman Ireland House                  New York University                  One Washington Mews                  New York, NY 10003                  U.S.A.
